title: How and when did Lanka become Sri Lanka? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sri Lanka in Sanskrit means "Blessed Land."  Lankans - so officially called the inhabitants of Sri Lanka. Ceylon - the former name of the country, until 1972. The Lancian burghers are an ethnic community in Sri Lanka, descendants of the marriages of Europeans with Lancians. Singing the days is a Buddhist holiday, which is celebrated every full moon. This is an official national day off, in which official institutions, banks, most shops and markets do not work. Also these days, the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited. The actual, but not the official capital of the country is the city of Colombo. The official capital is the city of Sri Jayavardenepur-Kotte The name "Colombo" comes from the Sinhalese "kola-amba-thota", which means "mango harbor". Alut Avurudu - the Lankan New Year, associated with the lunar cycles. It begins in accordance with the calculations of astrologers and is celebrated in April. Nonagatai is a neutral period (temporary vacuum) between the end of the old year and the beginning of a new one, which can take several hours. The difference between the maximum and minimum temperature during the year on the island does not exceed 5º C. The main religion of Sri Lanka is Buddhism, 70% of the population adhere to it. The remaining 20% ​​are Hindus and 10% are Muslims, Sikhs and Christians. The Tooth of the Buddha is one of the most revered Buddhist shrines in the city of Kandy and is kept in the Temple of the Tooth of the Buddha

According to the 1815 Kandyan Convention the original name of the country was "Sinhale"(in local language) or "Ceylon" (The Englishman's pronunciation of Sinhale) at the colonial time.  The name "Sri Lanka" was announced in the Sri Lankan Constitution of 1972 at the time of the president William Gopallawa. The most probable reason for this in the point of my view is Sinhalese are the majority of the country at the time and the name "Sinhale" or the "Ceylon" will express the ownership of the country to one ethnic group. So based on the concept of "multi ethnic society" the name may have been changed to "Sri Lanka".  Check Ancient Names of Sri Lanka to find more historical names for Sri Lanka.
